qas.question: Is there a consensus about the time that minority leadership officially emerged as a position?

answers.text: there is disagreement among historical analysts

context: In brief, <a0_0>there is disagreement among historical analysts<a0_0/> as to <b5_0>the exact time period<b5_0/> when the minority leadership emerged officially as <b3_0>a party position<b3_0/>. Nonetheless, it seems safe to conclude that the position emerged during <b4_0>the latter part of the 19th century<b4_0/>, a period of <a1_0>strong party organization and professional politicians<a1_0/>. This era was "marked by strong partisan attachments, resilient patronage-based party organizations, and...<b7_0>high levels<b7_0/> of party voting in Congress." Plainly, these were conditions conducive to the <a2_0>establishment of <b6_0>a more highly differentiated House leadership structure<b6_0/>.
